These efforts resemble not only what happened with SARS in 2002–2003, but also the Ebola virus outbreak in 2014–2015. During those outbreaks, special protocols were put in place to quarantine any infected individuals and identify patient contacts at risk
8 . Healthcare workers were also at risk, and despite extensive personal protective equipment measures, clinical providers did get infected in both outbreaks
9 . There were no specific, antiviral treatments for SARS or Ebola at the time of the outbreaks beyond supportive measures
10, 11 , which is a similar situation that healthcare systems are facing with 2019-nCoV.
